exploration_path.sentence_content: I started broad: a quick look at borough housing prices just to see what ‘attainable’ even means for a long-term purchase in London.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Choropleth—median house price by borough; (2) Ranked bars—price with London median band; (3) Filter chips—below- and near-median price bands

exploration_path.sentence_content: Price alone felt too blunt, so I reframed it as value: services per pound—how much schools and libraries you effectively get for the price you’d pay.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Index card—Value-per-Service = f(schools/10k + libraries/10k) ÷ price; (2) Scatter—value index vs price; (3) Toggle—limit to below/near-median price band

exploration_path.sentence_content: With that lens, I shortlisted boroughs that rank high on value-per-service while staying in the attainable price bands.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Ranked list—value-per-service within price band; (2) Shortlist panel—pin candidates; (3) Confidence ribbons—index stability

exploration_path.sentence_content: To make sure the schooling signal wasn’t just one hot spot, I checked whether top-quartile school access holds across multiple wards in each candidate.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Small multiples—schools per 10k by ward within each candidate; (2) Quartile overlay; (3) Consistency ticks

exploration_path.sentence_content: I added library coverage to confirm civic access is broad—not a single marquee branch that looks good on paper but doesn’t help day to day.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Libraries per 10k by ward; (2) Distribution chart—branches per ward; (3) Evenness badge—Gini-style spread indicator

exploration_path.sentence_content: Since neighborhood ‘fit’ matters over decades, I layered in cultural context—ethnicity diversity and country-of-birth variety—on the same shortlist.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Diversity index leaderboard—ethnicity entropy; (2) Country-of-birth variety gauge; (3) Overlay—diversity scores on candidates

exploration_path.sentence_content: First branch: I nudged up the candidates where diversity is already strong and still within the attainable price band—thinking long-term resilience and community breadth.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Filter—top diversity quartile ∧ price band; (2) Candidate chips—promoted set; (3) Note—assumption: diversity correlates with sustained desirability

exploration_path.sentence_content: I stress-tested those by checking co-location: do strong diversity scores sit alongside top-quartile schools and solid library coverage inside the same boroughs?
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Matrix—candidates × {diversity, schools, libraries}; (2) Heat cells—pass/fail; (3) Drill-through—ward maps for outliers

exploration_path.sentence_content: On schools, I looked for ward-level consistency so we’re not hanging a 20-year decision on a single catchment that could shift.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Ward-level schools small multiples; (2) Stability flag—proportion of wards in top quartile; (3) Catchment notes

exploration_path.sentence_content: On libraries, I checked that access is reasonably even across wards—multiple neighborhood branches rather than one central hub.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Branches-by-ward bar; (2) Evenness index card; (3) Map pins—branch spread

exploration_path.sentence_content: If diversity is strong but the sticker price is creeping up, I paused to see whether a slight premium still pencils out when service access is this good.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Price vs value-per-service scatter—highlight premium points; (2) Delta card—% above near-median; (3) ‘Premium test’ slider

exploration_path.sentence_content: Where the premium was small and services plus diversity were clearly superior, I kept the borough with a note that the extra up-front cost likely buys long-term stability.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Premium threshold acceptance; (2) Evidence summary—co-located strengths; (3) Flag—‘justified premium’

exploration_path.sentence_content: If the premium couldn’t be justified on services and community context, I dropped it back to the general pool and stuck to value-first candidates.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Premium threshold fail; (2) Demotion tag; (3) Return-to-shortlist action

exploration_path.sentence_content: Pulling the pieces together in this branch, I marked the diversity-plus-services boroughs as resilient buys, with caveats about ward consistency and any mild premium.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Branch synthesis card—{diversity, schools consistency, library evenness, premium note}; (2) Pin recommended set

exploration_path.sentence_content: Conclusion A (resilience): recommend the boroughs where strong cultural breadth co-exists with durable school access and even library coverage, at or near attainable prices.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Summary composer—resilience path; (2) Evidence links to all checks; (3) Persona tag—‘community breadth + services’

exploration_path.sentence_content: Second branch: I grouped the shortlisted boroughs by community profile—how ethnicity and country-of-birth patterns cluster—so buyers can compare like with like.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Cluster map—ethnicity/country-of-birth profile clusters; (2) Centroid cards—cluster signatures; (3) Candidate overlay

exploration_path.sentence_content: Inside each cluster, I kept the boroughs that stay in the attainable price band and clear baseline thresholds on schools and libraries.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Cluster filter ∧ price band; (2) Threshold badges—schools top half, libraries top half; (3) Keep/drop toggles

exploration_path.sentence_content: If a cluster match was great but schools were just outside the cutoff, I checked whether adjacent wards within the same borough compensate.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Ward adjacency map; (2) Spillover chart—nearby ward school density; (3) ‘Mitigated by adjacency’ flag

exploration_path.sentence_content: For libraries, I verified coverage isn’t lopsided; strong center-only access wasn’t enough for a decades-long plan.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Library coverage by ward; (2) Evenness badge; (3) Coverage heat strip

exploration_path.sentence_content: Where the community profile fit nicely but services were modest, I tested whether practical mitigations make it workable without exiting the price band.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Service baseline check; (2) Mitigation panel—nearby wards with higher services; (3) Price-band guardrail

exploration_path.sentence_content: If mitigations were real—nearby wards with stronger services while staying within the band—I kept the borough with a clear note about how to use the area.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Keep with caveat tag; (2) Mitigation route card; (3) Evidence link

exploration_path.sentence_content: If mitigations didn’t hold up, I downgraded it to an honorable mention for buyers prioritizing cultural match over convenience.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Downgrade badge; (2) Persona note—‘community-first, services second’; (3) Store as alternative

exploration_path.sentence_content: Conclusion B (profile-fit): present cluster-based recommendations that stay affordable, meet minimum school and library thresholds, and carry explicit caveats where applicable.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Summary composer—cluster path; (2) Persona cards per cluster; (3) Links to threshold and mitigation checks

exploration_path.sentence_content: To cross-check the rule-based picks, I also built a weighted score—schools, libraries, diversity—minus a penalty for higher prices.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Weight sliders {w_schools, w_libraries, w_diversity, w_price}; (2) Score formula card; (3) Ranked table by score

exploration_path.sentence_content: I ran a quick sensitivity analysis—swinging the weights ±15–20%—to see which boroughs stayed near the top no matter how you dial the priorities.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Tornado plot—rank stability; (2) Rank ribbons across weight ranges; (3) Stability badge

exploration_path.sentence_content: I tagged any borough that was top-ranked both under weighting and under the earlier rule logic as ‘robust’—these are the safest bets to defend.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Venn—score-top ∩ rule-top; (2) Robust tag on overlaps; (3) Filter—robust only

exploration_path.sentence_content: Method synthesis: the robust set aligns with at least one of the branches and doesn’t wobble when preferences shift—good news for a 10–20 year horizon.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Robust set card; (2) Links back to A/B evidence; (3) Persona presets mapping to weight ranges

exploration_path.sentence_content: Bringing it all together, I’d recommend the robust boroughs first, then offer the resilience path for buyers prioritizing community breadth with strong services, and the cluster-fit path for buyers seeking a specific cultural profile—with clear notes on price bands, ward consistency, and any justified premiums.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: (1) Final summary—three-lane recommendation (Robust, Resilience, Profile-Fit); (2) Evidence index—every claim linked to a chart; (3) Export pack—narrative + pinned views

data_story.data_story_sentence: Focusing on long-term attainability, an initial borough-level price scan established a below- and near-median housing price band as the search space.
We reframed affordability as value by normalizing access to schools and libraries per pound of purchase price.
This value-per-service lens surfaced a shortlist of boroughs that deliver strong public services while remaining within the attainable price bands.
Ward-level small multiples showed that school access is durable across catchments rather than concentrated in a single hotspot.
Library coverage exhibited an even spread of branches across wards, reducing hub-dependence risk for everyday access.
To incorporate community fit over a multi-decade horizon, we layered ethnicity diversity and country-of-birth variety onto the same candidate set.
Prioritizing high-diversity candidates that still met the price band highlighted areas with potential resilience in desirability.
Co-location checks verified that these high-diversity areas also sustained top-quartile schools alongside strong library networks.
School stability indicators confirmed that multiple wards—rather than a single catchment—meet or exceed the target access thresholds.
Library evenness metrics confirmed multiple neighborhood branches instead of a single central hub.
Where cultural breadth coincided with a mild price premium, we tested whether superior service access justified a small step-up above the near-median band.
Boroughs that cleared this premium test were retained as resilient buys given their combined service and community advantages.
Where the premium could not be justified on services and context, candidates were returned to the general pool and the value-first shortlist.
Synthesizing these checks, we marked diversity-plus-services boroughs as resilience picks, annotated with ward-consistency and premium notes where applicable.
Conclusion A (resilience): recommend boroughs where strong cultural breadth co-exists with durable school access and even library coverage at or near attainable prices.
In parallel, cluster analysis grouped candidates by community profile to support like-for-like comparisons for buyers seeking specific cultural contexts.
Within each profile cluster, we retained boroughs that stayed inside the price band and cleared baseline thresholds for schools and libraries.
Adjacency checks showed that near-cutoff school access can be supported by neighboring wards within the same borough.
Library coverage reviews filtered out cases with overly centralized access, preserving only boroughs with broadly distributed branches.
Where profile fit was strong but services were modest, practical mitigations preserved viability without breaching the price band.
When mitigations held—via nearby higher-service wards while staying within band—we kept the option with explicit usage notes.
Conclusion B (profile-fit): present cluster-based recommendations that remain affordable, meet minimum school and library thresholds, and carry clear caveats where needed.
To cross-validate selections, we built a weighted composite score over schools, libraries, and diversity with a price penalty.
Sensitivity analysis—swinging weights by ±15–20%—assessed rank stability under different buyer priorities.
Boroughs that stayed near the top across weight swings and also appeared in the rule-based branches were tagged as robust.
These robust candidates provide defensible anchors for a 10–20-year horizon, independent of small shifts in emphasis.

Final guidance prioritizes robust candidates first, followed by resilience-path picks for community breadth with strong services, and cluster-fit matches for specific cultural profiles, each tied to price-band and network-evenness evidence.
